div.p: S. P. D. I have not yet received any letters from you, doubting that you have not received mine; for I am held by a burning desire for your letters. My dearest father has placed me together with my cousin in the college of Prélès with a learned and erudite teacher, whom I believe will not fail in his efforts to educate us, and I will not lack the spirit, and I believe I will spend my time so well that I will fulfill my duty to you satisfactorily.
Moreover, if you wish to know about our health, know that I am enjoying good health, which I wish you may also enjoy.
I have nothing new now to write or send to you; but at another time, when I have more leisure, I will write to you more extensively.
Thus, I will end my letter.
I ask you to greet, in my name, Veritas and Dorothea and all our most familiar acquaintances whom you know. All my dearest parents and Stuckius send you many greetings.
Farewell in Christ, who may always keep you safe. Given in the study on the fourth day before the Nones of December 1565.
Your always most beloved and always most obedient son Matthieu Coignet.
To the most learned and distinguished man, Mr. Heinrich Bullinger, father, most vigilant of the church of Zurich, to be greatly respected. In Zurich.
